Award.AbstractNarration:
Using the known photochemistry of the ultraviolet and visible photolysis of nitrate as a study system, the interfacial aqueous phase ice-atmosphere surface photo-oxidation mechanisms expected to be active in snow, firn and on atmospheric ice-crystals are to be investigated.

Advanced surface techniques such as in-situ (ambient pressure) X-ray photoelectron spectroscopies (AP PES) and in-situ near edge X-ray absorption fine structure (NEXAFS) will characterize, at the molecular level, the interactions of probe hydrocarbons, in the presence and absence of nitric acid, in the Quasi-Liquid film layer (QLL) that covers solid ice surfaces. Actinic irradiation ( > 300 nm) of sorbed nitrate will yield an experimental system capable of studying reactivity of OH radicals with target hydrocarbons. This is in turn to lead to a broader understanding of the importance of these surface photochemical mechanisms relevant to snow-pack and ice chemistry of polar and cold regions of the atmosphere at intermediate, yet environmentally relevant, temperatures (> -20C to 0 C).

Dr John Newberg has been awarded an OPP Post-Doctoral Fellowship to conduct this research under the mentorship of Dr Hendrik Blum, Chemical Sciences, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory. The project is interdisicplinary, and is supported by the OPP-AOAS, GEO- Atmospheric Chemistry, and MPS - Environmental Chemical Sciences programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The scientific goal of this research was to understand the chemistry of organic compounds when exposed to ice and sunlight, which are ubiquitous in the natural environment. Reactions within the ice can lead to other molecules which can then evaporate and affect the chemistry of the surrounding air. The findings of this research show that the chemistry of organic molecules can be much different when they are in contact with frozen ice, as opposed to being in contact with liquid water. This has significant implications when studying the environmental chemistry of organic compounds, and will help scientists in the ice chemistry community to understand how long these molecules persist, and how fast they can degrade and affect the surrounding air in environments such as Polar Regions.

During the two years of this funded project the PI worked at a highly regarded synchrotron at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory operated by the U.S. Department of Energy, and got exposure to world class, unique research equipment. Many researchers from all over come to use this equipment, and the PI had the privilege to collaborate with a number of them.

Mentorship and outreach was also a major component of this project. The PI mentored a postbaccalaureate student full time during Spring 2012. This involved training the intern on new scientific instrumentation and ice photochemistry related problems. This also involved the development of literature search skills, writing skills, and presentation skills. The intern produced a final report and presented a poster on the research results. This intern has gone on to pursue a Masters degree in science, and has ambitions to work towards a PhD and ultimately obtain a PhD level science position. The PI has also exposed 100+ third grade students to a focused one hour science session aimed at demonstrating phase transitions between a solid, liquid, and gas, and also at exposing these children to real people who are passionate about doing science as a career.

The scientific equipment acquired from this grant has carried over into the PI’s current research faculty position, and is therefore contributing to the research infrastructure of the PI's new institution. Moreover, a number of the topics covered in this research grant is currently part of the PI's current teaching curriculum for a graduate course in heterogeneous atmospheric chemistry.
